title: 106_s3183
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., Commemorative Coin Act". Congress acknowledges Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s dedication to securing liberty and justice for all citizens, his leadership in the civil rights movement, and his famous "I Have A Dream" speech delivered at the March on Washington in 1963. He was a strong advocate of nonviolence. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. advocated nonviolent resistance to end segregation and racial discrimination in America, earning him the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize. Americans should honor his legacy to achieve equality. Efforts are being made to preserve his personal papers for future study at the Library of Congress. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $1 silver coins weighing 26.73 grams, with a diameter of 1.500 inches, containing 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and the silver for minting will be sourced from various available sources, including stockpiles. The design of the coins will be determined. The design of the coins minted under this Act shall symbolize Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s human rights legacy. Each coin will feature a value designation, the year "2003", and inscriptions of "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with various entities and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. SEC. 6. ISSUANCE OF COINS.

Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single designated facility of the United States Mint. The Secretary is authorized to issue these coins only during a one-year period starting on January 1, 2003. SEC. 7. SALE OF COINS.

The coins will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and all sales will include a $10 surcharge per coin. SEC. 8. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. Surcharges from coin sales will be promptly paid to the Library of Congress for purchasing and maintaining historical documents related to Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.
